title: Sufjan Stevens blasts the Grammys as racist after Beyoncé loses
text:
Sufjan Stevens, St. Vincent blast the Grammys for being racist after Beyoncé loses in major categories Sufjan Stevens blasts the Grammys as racist after Beyoncé loses Beyoncé accepts the Grammy for Best Urban Contemporary Album for "Lemonade" from presenter William Bell at the 59th Annual Grammy Awards on Feb. 12. (LUCY NICHOLSON/REUTERS)   8:44 AM 
Beyoncé's snubs were noticed around the world. 
Indie rocker Sufjan Stevens accused the Academy of being racist for not awarding the Queen Bey Grammys in major categories. 
"Q: WTF is Urban Contemporary'?" he wrote on his Tumblr , referencing the one award the "Lemonade" artist did take home. Sufjan Stevens slams the Grammys as racist for overlooking Beyoncé for the major awards. (Evan Agostini/Evan Agostini/Invision/AP) 
He answered, "It's where the white man puts the [incomparable] pregnant black woman because he is so threatened by her talent, power, persuasion and potential." 
"Friendly reminder: don't be racist," he added. 
St. Vincent's Annie Clark agreed, writing on Twitter: "What Sufjan said." 
Adele's "25" beat out "Lemonade" for Album of the Year, a choice that even Adele herself found questionable. 
"What the f--k does she have to do to win album of the year? That's how I feel," the "Hello" singer said of Beyoncé. Best moments from the Grammys 2017 
She tweeted — and later deleted — a strong message about the Grammys. 
“There have only been two black winners in the last 20 years for album of the year there have been over 200 black artist who have performed,” she wrote. 
The younger Knowles also tweeted out a link to Frank Ocean’s Tumblr post where he explained Kendrick Lamar’s loss to Taylor Swift last year, noting that the Grammys were responsible for “cultural bias.” Adele gave a shout out to Beyoncé in the audience while accepting the Grammy for Song of the Year. (LUCY NICHOLSON/REUTERS) 
“wuddup frank,” Solange tweeted along with the link, hinting her sister’s snub was one in the same. 
The "Formation" singer's losses have shined a light on a larger issue with the award ceremony, leading people to question whether it really could be a race issue. 
Beyoncé lost to Adele in the following categories: Album of the year, Record of the year, Song of the year, Pop Solo performance, but took home the award for Urban Contemporary Album and Music video for "Formation." Join the Conversation:
